abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Mining Development
            and Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project is
            rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The key lessons drawn include: Sector
            development should be part of an overall political and
            economic reform. This project provides a good example of the
            importance to approach sector reform in an integrated way.
            It is critical to design and implement during project
            preparation and implementation a more systematic social
            strategy, including improved information and consultation
            participatory process. The geo-scientific information
            management represents a very valuable tool not only for
            sector development but also for land use and related
            potential conflicts management. The project has demonstrated
            the importance to use an integrated approach and to
            emphasize the socio-economic aspects related to the
            subsector situation to address artisanal and small-scale
            mining issues. The involvement and balance of foreign versus
            national expertise in project activities is an issue much
            debated with respect to technical assistance capacity
            building impact and sustainability. It is important for
            sectoral institutions and their staff to develop a strong
            commitment to reform and acquire a full sense of ownership
            and responsibility for the project.
